data.name: Point in a polygon with curves
data.description:
# Point in a Polygon with curves Given a 2d polygon description and a point coordinate, determine whether the point exists inside or outside the polygon. The polygon may be simple or complex, and can include curves. The polygon description must be for a closed polygon, in which the first and last point described are the same. The polygon description will use three operators: moveto, lineto, and curveto, similar to a subset of Postscript path operators. 'moveto' sets the current x y point 'lineto' draws a boundary to the next x y point, which becomes the new current x y point 'curveto' draws a Bezier cubic spline, starting at the current x y point, and ending at the fourth (third supplied) point A typical polygon descriptor ```javascript var thisPolygon = {'polygon' : [ {'moveto' : {'x' : 10, 'y' : 10}}, {'lineto' : {'x' : 20, 'y' : 10}}, {'curveto' : [{'x' : 25, 'y' : 12}, {'x' : 25, 'y' : 18}, {'x' : 20, 'y' : 20}]}, {'lineto' : {'x' : 10, 'y' : 20}}, {'lineto' : {'x' : 10, 'y' : 10}} ]}; ``` A typical point descriptor ```javascript var thisPoint = {'x' : 12, 'y' : 18}; ``` A good starting point for the point in polygon algorithm test can be found here: http://www.ecse.rpi.edu/Homepages/wrf/Research/Short_Notes/pnpoly.html There are other examples as well. It will require that any curves be rendered into straight-line segments. Given a polygon and a point, the pointInPoly function will return true if the point is in side the polygon, false if it is outside, or a string: 'Error!' if the polygon is not closed properly. (This last because the Test.expectError() call does not seem to handle errors as stated.) # About Bezier splines From the Adobe Postscript Reference Manual:
Mathematically, a cubic BÃ©zier curve is derived from a pair of parametric cubic equations:
x(t) = axt3 + bxt2 + cxt + x0
y(t) = ayt3 + byt2 + cyt + y0
The cubic section produced by curveto is the path traced by x(t) and y(t) as t ranges from 0 to 1.
But don't panic, there is an easier way. The Bezier cubic spline consists of two end points and two control points: Source http://wikipedia.com To plot the midpoint of the curve, find the midpoints of the three vectors between the four points (P01, P12, P23). Find the midpoints between those three points (P012, P123). Find the final midpoint between those two points (P0123). Source: http://www.deluge.co This may seem unnecessarily complicated, but since a lot of the calculation is simply dividing by two, it can be done very quickly with binary bit shift operations. This meant a lot in 1984, as PostScript was heading to market in early laser printers. Complex curves could be described and plotted with minimal computation. Notice that the two remaining point sets (P0, P01, P012 and P0123) and (P0123, P123, P23 and P3) describe the next two Bezier curves down. One can recurse this function to the precision needed, and return all the points to form the straight-line segments for the polygon. Another way to do this is to plot a percentage of each midpoint, and range across them to the end: 10% of the distance from each point and midpoint to the next, 20%, 30%, etc. will product 10 line segments whose endpoints are on the described curve. Adjust your precision as necessary. Source: https://github.com/mammenx/synesthesia_zen/wiki/Curve-Surfing
